thread.title: The best European music festivals you can fly to from Manchester Airport in 2017
thread.title_full: The best European music festivals you can fly to from Manchester Airport in 2017

author: Matthew Cooper
title: The best European music festivals you can fly to from Manchester Airport in 2017
text:
What's On The best European music festivals you can fly to from Manchester Airport in 2017 Not fond of Glastonbury? Coachella too expensive? European festivals like Lowlands, Bilbao BBK Live and Lolla Paris all offer sun, sea and sounds. Better yet, you can fly to many of them from right here in Manchester Share Way Out West, Gothenburg, Sweden (Photo: Nora Loek) Share Get What's On   Thank you for subscribing!   
2017 is here, which means that before too long the summer will be creeping into view and people will start saying things like 'festival season'. 
This of course means that longer evenings, barbecues and prolonged periods of rain are just around the corner. 
With summer comes festival season (told you), and if you’re already going to one of the many fests in this country you'll be hoping it’ll be a weekend where the prolonged periods of rain are elsewhere. 
But if potential rain isn’t a risk you are willing to take and parking in a waterlogged marsh moonlighting as a car park isn’t enticing then maybe you should head for the continent to satisfy your thirst for culture, art and warm beer. You also get to visit somewhere new and broaden your cultural horizons. 
Better yet, the majority of festivals in Europe are near major airports that you can fly to directly from Manchester. Meaning you can travel from the North of England to central Germany in less than half the time you’d spend in a traffic jam outside Glastonbury. 
Whether you want to hear dance on the beach of Croatia or get lost in the woods in Latvia, here are some of the most interesting festivals to visit in 2017. Roskilde Festival 
Where: Roskilde, West of Copenhagen, Denmark 
When: 24 June - 1 July 2017 
Taking place in Scandinavia’s most southerly country, Roskilde takes in over 100,000 visitors over its week long programme. The festival has been held here since the 1970s and is an exploration through music, art, food, community and more. The festival is also 100% non-profit and has been since day one. Created by extremely dedicated volunteers all profits are donated to cultural and humanitarian purposes by the Roskilde Festival Charity Society. 
Lineup: The Weeknd, Foo Fighters, Arcade Fire, Justice, Solange, Cashmere Cat, Warpaint + more. 
Airport: Copenhagen
